story:
Lend A Hand to Help Teddy Move into his new Future

On January 11, 2013, Teddy Churchill suffered a major stroke.  As fate would have it Teddy's sister Paige is an OR Nurse on staff at Cape Cod Hospital and found him a short time after his stroke had occurred and called 911.  Teddy was airlifted to Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, MA.  It was touch and go as to his condition due to major brain clot and paralysis.  While his injuries were extremely serious, Ted's recovery has astonished his family, friends, and doctors up to this point.

Ted's will to improve has been amazing.  Some side affects of the stoke have been facial paralysis, vision issues in his left eye, aphasia, apraxia, some short term memory loss and a heart condition undiagnosed until now.  Though he has overcome so much in such a short time already, Teddy has a great deal of recovery and hurdles to overcome in his future.

Anyone who knows Teddy truly appreciates his creativity, kindness, humor and sense of style.   

Due to this sudden tragedy Teddy has decided to shut down is catering business "Cucina di Amore" which was even featured in the May 2012 Issue of Cape Cod Magazine!  "Cucina Di Amore" was Teddy's only source of income and it is our hope that along with continuing to recover from these devistating health issues, Ted finds a new path in life, a way to generate a new source of income. 

To help Teddy with his recovery effort we're reaching out to anyone willing to donate.  All donations will go directly to Teddy's recovery to help with upcoming medical expenses and needs.  Hopefully, with everyone’s support and help Ted can make a fresh start for himself!  

Please contribute what you can to help Teddy. NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL...Whether you have $5 to spare or $100, ANYTHING HELPS!

story:
SPRYNG™ is an affordable, untethered, pneumatic compression wrap that helps improve circulation, athletic performance, and so much more.

Whether you’ve had a rough leg day, spent hours sitting in a cubicle, or just finished a marathon, SPRYNG™ is the ultimate tool that you’ll love and use every day.

What Is Active Compression?

Active leg compression is a form of compression that mimics natural muscle contractions in your calves. It helps improve circulation, increase cellular oxygen supply, and stimulate tissue repair.

Active Compression helps:

By compressing your legs, you encourage circulation of blood where it needs the most support. This, in turn, can help reduce swelling and usher in fresh blood, nutrients, and lymphatic fluid to your legs to help accelerate healing and recovery.

Supporting Circulation In Your Legs

Due to gravity, your legs usually have the worst circulation in your body- especially if you’re standing or sitting all day. Without active circulation through your calves, blood will pool at your feet - resulting in swelling and pain.

When your muscle pump remains inactive, you risk blood pooling, and inhibit circulation throughout your body (the blood in your feet is the same blood that is circulated through your heart and to your brain).

This is why we focus on actively compressing your legs to help get that blood moving!

The Benefits of Improved Circulation

Active Compression is an effective way to improve circulation, flush lactic acid, and increase oxygenation to muscle tissues to get you back on your feet faster. Get more oxygen throughout your body and higher performance.

Improved Circulation can help:

Passive Compression Just Doesn’t Cut It

You’ve likely encountered other compression tools such as socks, wraps, and sleeves.

The main issue with these passive compression accessories is that they don’t do much when you’re in an office, plane, car, kitchen - anywhere you’ll be sitting or standing.

Passive compression only provides support when you are using your muscle pump. In other words, they only work when you’re ALREADY active - in a workout or on a walk/run.

This is where Active Compression comes in.

Active Compression actively MIMICS the action of the calf muscle pump without you needing to do anything!

The Beauty of Active Compression

The Problem With Other Devices

Current devices are ineffective or only accessible to professional athletes. These devices end up being bulky, covered in wires and hoses, not portable, and extremely expensive.

They can have poor compression patterns that don’t use active compression, don’t match the muscle pump, or, worse, do more harm than good by pushing blood in the wrong direction.

  • Bulky - complicated, heavy, not portable
  • Expensive - reserved for high-paying professional athletes
  • Poor Compression Pattern - dangerous and harmful

The Power of SPRYNG™

Using our patent-pending WaveTech compression pattern, SPRYNG™ effectively mimics your skeletal muscle pump - which means it is the best way to help enhance your body’s natural circulatory flow.

This means you get safe, powerful, and effective active compression that compliments your body’s natural rhythm. 

No reverse flow (which can get dangerous) - SPRYNG™ makes sure your blood goes where it needs to go, the way it’s supposed to go, faster and more effectively.

Patent-Pending WaveTech Pattern

Our unique patent-pending compression patterns actively and gently push your blood in the right direction and work with the natural flow of your body.


                  They do this by mimicking the skeletal muscle pump that acts as a second heart - aiding the return of blood to your core to help reduce swelling and muscle injury.

You’ll feel your blood circulating through your calves, up your thighs, and through your body fluidly and powerfully. Relax as your body enters accelerated flow.

Strategic Pneumatic Pressure

We compartmentalized the compression areas to three strategic parts of your calf to make sure we help maximize blood flow and the efficacy of the compression.

Feel the powerful massage hit just the right spots.

Targeted Compression Affects Your Whole Leg

Not just for your calves! Improving circulation at the lower extremities naturally helps push blood upwards through your thighs towards the heart. As a result, the lower extremities of your legs are one of the best targets to help improve blood circulation.

Synchronized Compression

SPRYNG™ isn’t just synced with your naturally occurring muscle pump and blood circulation, it syncs with its adjoining pair automatically.

Through the use of Infrared technology, each SPRYNG™ device connects and syncs with its pair to give you dual active compression.

The patterns in each leg will be synced up and matched, so you have a cohesive and comfortable session in complete harmony. 

3 Levels Of Intensity

Simply press the intensity button to increase or decrease the level of compression intensity you want.

Internal sensors ensure SPRYNG™ never pushes beyond your comfort, so you know you’re in good hands!

Choose between two powerful compression patterns:

3 Steps To Setup

Untethered Performance

SPRYNG™ is completely wireless and tubeless. You can use it in whatever position and any situation. Simply strap it on and let it run! There’s nothing to plug in or connect - a fully untethered experience.

Compact & Portable

Not only is SPRYNG™ wireless, it’s also small and compact. You can easily fit it in your bag and even use it on a plane.

Through its unique design and patent-pending compression pattern, you’ll get improved circulation throughout your entire leg with just a small area of compression. The device only wraps around your ankle and calves, so you can remain totally mobile without clunkiness or constraint.

Feels Amazing

Did we mention? SPRYNG™ feels absolutely incredible! We honestly can’t talk about it enough. The pneumatic compression is like a a deep tissue leg massage that helps circulate your blood, pull out pain, and relax your entire body.

Check out what users had to say about it!

Long-Lasting Battery

SPRYNG™ has a powerful battery that can give up to 2.5 hours of active use. That means you can have up to 10 sessions before needing a recharge.

The device can be easily recharged via micro-usb cable.

One Size Fits Most

Whether you have large legs or tiny calves, SPRYNG™ has you in mind. We used a one-size-fits-most model using velcro straps to attach the device.

The straps are fully adjustable, so you can switch sizes quickly and easily.

Machine-Washable

Sweaty legs? Not a problem! The inner layer of SPRYNG™ can be removed and is 100% machine washable.

Sustainable & Affordable

Pneumatic active compression used to be reserved only for professional athletes, universities, and the uber-rich. Now, we’re bringing its performance enhancing powers to you for a tenth of the cost (that’s 90% off)!

You’ll not just be getting the same effects, but you’ll have it better, faster, and much more portable than the rest.

Throughout this process, we were heavily influenced and inspired by video games. We loved the artwork, design, and mechanics found in these fictional, digital worlds and wanted to create a regeneration tool like those seen in games.

With SPRYNG™, we believe we got pretty close. 

Naturally, we felt our outer layer skin designs should reflect this achievement. So we designed our outer skins to have four unique colorways that draw homage to our favorite video game experiences. 

SPRYNG™ is your real-life power boost and looks it too!

SPRYNG™ isn’t just for athletes! If you stand or sit a lot, you need to get blood circulating to stay healthy, relieve tired and achy legs, and help increase cognitive performance! This means Spryng is perfect for everyone!

From DJs to Moms to CEOs and gamers, get higher level performance across all areas of life! 

 

Several years ago our team was focused on looking at one significant leg condition – diabetic neuropathy. When we dug deep into the realms of neuropathy we realized that a method called active compression could be a wonderful solution to this. That took us down the route of looking at active compression and the technologies we could use to achieve this. 

In our journey, the more we researched, the more we realized that active compression could not only offer a potential solution for diabetic neuropathy, but it had far more expansive potential therapeutic effects. It was something that could benefit tens of millions of people all over the world. 

Sadly, a lot of the active compression solutions that were out there were either very very expensive or were used in hospital settings that were inaccessible for many people. We wanted to do it differently. We wanted to bring active compression to everyone out there. Hence, we created Spryng! 

Through Spryng, we want to bring the benefits of active compression in an easy to use and affordable manifestation to all of you!
story_txt:
SPRYNG™ is an affordable, untethered, pneumatic compression wrap that helps improve circulation, athletic performance, and so much more.Whether you’ve had a rough leg day, spent hours sitting in a cubicle, or just finished a marathon, SPRYNG™ is the ultimate tool that you’ll love and use every day.


 

 


Check out our interview with Digital Trends.


 What Is Active Compression?Active leg compression is a form of compression that mimics natural muscle contractions in your calves. It helps improve circulation, increase cellular oxygen supply, and stimulate tissue repair.Active Compression helps:By compressing your legs, you encourage circulation of blood where it needs the most support. This, in turn, can help reduce swelling and usher in fresh blood, nutrients, and lymphatic fluid to your legs to help accelerate healing and recovery.Supporting Circulation In Your LegsDue to gravity, your legs usually have the worst circulation in your body- especially if you’re standing or sitting all day. Without active circulation through your calves, blood will pool at your feet - resulting in swelling and pain.When your muscle pump remains inactive, you risk blood pooling, and inhibit circulation throughout your body (the blood in your feet is the same blood that is circulated through your heart and to your brain).This is why we focus on actively compressing your legs to help get that blood moving!The Benefits of Improved CirculationActive Compression is an effective way to improve circulation, flush lactic acid, and increase oxygenation to muscle tissues to get you back on your feet faster. Get more oxygen throughout your body and higher performance.Improved Circulation can help:Passive Compression Just Doesn’t Cut ItYou’ve likely encountered other compression tools such as socks, wraps, and sleeves.The main issue with these passive compression accessories is that they don’t do much when you’re in an office, plane, car, kitchen - anywhere you’ll be sitting or standing.Passive compression only provides support when you are using your muscle pump. In other words, they only work when you’re ALREADY active - in a workout or on a walk/run.This is where Active Compression comes in.Active Compression actively MIMICS the action of the calf muscle pump without you needing to do anything!The Beauty of Active CompressionThe Problem With Other DevicesCurrent devices are ineffective or only accessible to professional athletes. These devices end up being bulky, covered in wires and hoses, not portable, and extremely expensive.They can have poor compression patterns that don’t use active compression, don’t match the muscle pump, or, worse, do more harm than good by pushing blood in the wrong direction.
Bulky - complicated, heavy, not portable
Expensive - reserved for high-paying professional athletes
Poor Compression Pattern - dangerous and harmful
The Power of SPRYNG™Using our patent-pending WaveTech compression pattern, SPRYNG™ effectively mimics your skeletal muscle pump - which means it is the best way to help enhance your body’s natural circulatory flow.This means you get safe, powerful, and effective active compression that compliments your body’s natural rhythm. No reverse flow (which can get dangerous) - SPRYNG™ makes sure your blood goes where it needs to go, the way it’s supposed to go, faster and more effectively.Patent-Pending WaveTech PatternOur unique patent-pending compression patterns actively and gently push your blood in the right direction and work with the natural flow of your body.                  They do this by mimicking the skeletal muscle pump that acts as a second heart - aiding the return of blood to your core to help reduce swelling and muscle injury.You’ll feel your blood circulating through your calves, up your thighs, and through your body fluidly and powerfully. Relax as your body enters accelerated flow.Strategic Pneumatic PressureWe compartmentalized the compression areas to three strategic parts of your calf to make sure we help maximize blood flow and the efficacy of the compression.Feel the powerful massage hit just the right spots.Targeted Compression Affects Your Whole LegNot just for your calves! We want our backers to have a great experience with SPRYNG™. story:
The Project

Projects for Underserved Communities (PUC) is a course at The University of Texas at Austin that brings together social work and engineering students to collaborate on analyzing, designing, and implementing sustainable projects that have a high impact in underdeveloped communities across the globe.

The Mangiang Water Initiative is focused on implementing a solar water pumping system in the community of Mangiang, Papua New Guinea. Mangiang is a close-knit community of about 600 people. Currently, the villagers get the water they use for cleaning and bathing by digging holes by the side of local river, and carrying the water back in heavy yellow buckets. Water in the river has possible exposure to pesticide contanimated runoff from farms upstream and is far from meeting quality standards for sanitary bathing and drinking water. 

In the village there are three wells and a borehole, sources of untested water currently used for drinking. Villagers are able to haul buckets of water out of one of the wells for drinking, and the other three sources lie defunct. In addition, the village is too remote to be connected to a power grid. Our team will address this issue by cleaning out their usable well, purifying the water, installing a submersible DC pump that is powered by a photovoltaic array, and implement a gravity-powered distribution system in a central location, creating easy, reliable access to clean water for 20+ years. 

The importance of clean drinking water cannot be understressed. Unsanitary drinking water poses a variety of health concerns. By fixing this well, we would be reducing the community's exposure to waterborne illnesses. Access to clean water will be fufilling a fundamental need for the entire community.

Your involvement with this project will make a huge impact on the lives of the people of Mangiang. Something as simple as access to clean water will cause a marked increase in the standard of living for this community. Every contribution helps us get closer to our goal -- every bit gets us closer to making a difference!

How is Mangiang Involved?

To make this project sustainable, community members of Mangiang will actively participate in the construction of the solar water pumping system, and take charge of managing the distribution of water and continued upkeep. During our stay in Papua New Guinea, our team will assist the community in forming and organizing a Water Users Committee, which will be responsible for guarding and maintaining the solar water pumping system. This committee will be composed completely from the men and women of Mangiang. We will also be holding educational classes and activities to teach Mangiang on the importance of clean water and how solar energy and the pumping system works.

We have been working closely with the Appropriate Technology and Community Development Institute (ATCDI) at The University of Technology in Lae, Papua New Guinea to collaborate with Mangiang on this project. They are looking forward to seeing us there this summer, and we can't wait to meet them!

All materials, tools, and labor for this project will be purchased or hired in-country. That means everything is locally sourced in Papua New Guinea to support local business.

Our Team

The Mangiang Water Initiative is a team comprised of six students attending The University ofTexas at Austin.

Taylor Nordstrom, Project Manager, is a third-year Civil Engineering student graduating in May 2014. Taylor is a Senior Resident Assistant, where she supervises over 40 undergraduate students as well as a teaching assistant in the Department of Mechanical Engineering. She is an avid traveler and has studied abroad in France. Taylor is interested in sustainable energy and technical writing and plans to pursue a career in water resource management.

Ashwin Ramaswami, Assistant Project Manager/Technical Lead, is a sophomore in the Department of Biomedical Engineering. He has traveled to many countries including India, China, Malaysia, and Costa Rica. He participates in campus community involvement organizations, such as Habitat for Humanity and SEEK, a mentoring program for young students. Ashwin’s academic interests include rehabilitative biomechanics as well as economics, and upon graduation in 2015, he intends to attend graduate school, and eventually pursueing a career in the medical device industry.

Nita Soni, Quality and Standards Manager, is a second year Mechanical Engineering student. Nita is currently working on two projects with Engineers for a Sustainable World, including a solar-powered smoothie cart, and, through the university Robotics and Automation Society, has mentored a team of first-year students in a Robotathon competition. She greatly enjoys outreach and working with communities and plans to focus her studies on sustainable engineering. Nita enjoys traveling, and has visited Mexico and Thailand.

Manav Mandhani, Travel Logistics and Scope Manager, is a second-year Electrical and Computer Engineering student graduating in May 2015. He is an Indian citizen who was born and raised in the United Arab Emirates. Manav is currently a student assistant at the Engineering Sciences lab checkout desk. He is interested in renewable energy and software development, and plans on pursuing community development with emphasis on education in the future.

Crystal Cassimere, Communications Manager, is a fourth-year Social Work student expecting to graduate in December 2013. Crystal plans to pursue a career in nursing after she graduates. She is currently a certified nurse aide and a part of several health organizations at the university. Crystal has traveled abroad to San Jose, Costa Rica to set up free health clinics and to give donations to different communities. Crystal is interested in working with and helping similar communities around the world.

Kristen Palughi, Risk Analysis and Safety Manager, is a second-year Mechanical Engineering student graduating in May 2015. Kristen is currently the Historian of the campus Robotics and Automation Society as well as an involved member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers and the Women in Engineering Program. She has previous experience working with solar power from designing a solar-powered electric bicycle charging station and building a successful prototype. 

 

Your Pledge

Where is the $3500 going? 

Before we can purchase the materials and components of the solar water pumping system, we must travel to Papua New Guinea to meet face-to-face with our Papua New Guinean contacts. Faculty advisors will be acting as representatives for our team, and will be the ones traveling to Papua New Guinea in our stead for this reconnaissance trip, from April 19th to April 24th. The majority of our budget is for their in-country travel, the remainder for procuring the materials for conducting the necessary tests.

Together, we will be analyzing and approving design specifications, survey the working site, conduct the necessary testing, conduct risk analysis, and locate future sources of materials for our implementation.

Any additional funding will be put towards future projects completed by the university's Projects for Underserved Communities teams. 

For online, tax-deductible donations you can also donate directly to PUC at the Projects for Underserved Communities website.

https://utdirect.utexas.edu/apps/utgiving/online/nlogon/?menu1=ENPC&source=PUC

 

If you can't donate....

You can still help out by spreading the word!

Thank you for your time and for reading this page; your every effort is very appreciated! 

 

If you have any questions, please feel free to e-mail our team at puc.png@gmail.com.

story:
Hidradenitis Suppurativa - I have had this incurable disease since I turned 20, I am now 27 years old and the disease worsens with each year that passes. It is an extremely debilitating, highly embarrassing and painful disease that causes sweat glands to be blocked which then causes multiple large painful boils in the groin, armpits, under breasts, stomach, buttox and anywhere else you sweat. When I have a breakout I am left in crippling pain and most times unable to walk. It is a hideous, disfiguring disease and there are very few people who even know I have it, mainly because I am ashamed. I cannot swim or do activities with my kids, walking is limited, I cannot wear shorts or tank tops, I have to take time off of work constantly because I cannot walk or sit down without experiencing excruciating pain. My kids never understand why mommy cant play for very long or why i opt out of walks to the park whenever possible. I am sure my employers think I am a terrible employee that lies about being sick all the time. I have been ashamed of my body my entire adult life, my quality of life depends on how much pain I can withstand to put smiles on my children's faces. for example: a trip to the zoo 20-30 min of walking and the next day I will have 2-3 large boils that cannot be drained for two to three days, I am unable to walk and have to take advil like there's no tomorrow. I have seen six doctors in seven years, including leading dermatologists. Doctors are very uneducated in this disease mainly because it is grossly overlooked in the medical research area. Most refuse to give the pain medication required to get any sort of relief because they don't know enough about the severity of the pain caused by this disease. Most of the doctors including my family doctor won't even look me in the eye and nine times out of ten, they throw antibiotics at me and call it a day. I have had two natural childbirths and I would rather experience labour pain than the pain caused by this disease any day.... I diagnosed myself through research and only then was it confirmed by doctors. Previously one doctor diagnosed me with acne, one with metabolic syndrome, some told me it was temporary and to just keep taking antibiotics. Ive tried everything the doctors have prescribed and suggested as well as hundreds of home remedies to no avail.

I've been a one woman medical research team for years and now I am reaching out because I know that there are people who can look past the repulsion of the disease and see the woman, the mother and help a fellow human in need. I have Exposed my most shameful and well-kept secret for the world to see so that I can continue to afford to try new experimental treatments in hopes of one day being the active mother and wife I know I was meant to be. In addition, I want to create a support website for people suffering with this disease so that none of us will have feel alone anymore.

I work two jobs, I work through the pain because I have no choice. By the time I get home I am in pain and am unable to function like a normal mother and wife. I will do anything for my family and they are the sole reason I have not given up. It would be amazing if I could give up one of my jobs for a while to focus more on treatment and research for my disease. Please google the disease and see for yourself. I truly appreciate any help I can get and thank you for reading.

story:
Our Campaign is for our son Ty, he's a 16 year old cancer survivor. After 10 months of high dose chemo therapy and a surgery, our son became an above knee amputee due to bone cancer in his right tibia. Though he won't always be a cancer patient, he will always be an amputee.

We have been blessed with having decent health insurance due to my husband being active duty and serving in the US Air Force for 21 years. Now retired and not able to find a job and 70% disabled, it's becoming harder for us to afford to pay out of pocket cost for new prosthetic legs as Ty continues to grow.

Right now Ty is learning to play Ice Hockey and he wants to play standing up, not in a sled. We just found out that due to the new health care laws our insurance provider will loose it's contract at the end of the month, which means our out of pocket cost for Prosthetics will skyrocket. Our Co-Pays could go from 12 dollars a visit to 300. Ty has to have many fittings with his Prosthetist in order to have a leg that will allow him to be independent.

For Ty, being able to play Ice Hockey like everyone else is more than just being normal, it will give him a sense of independence that a person deserves, he will no longer have to go sit on the bleachers with friends during stick time and watch, he will be able to suit up and play the game he has come to love so much.

We have set the goal to what we are expected to pay for just this one leg, anything that exceeds the goal will be set aside for a fund for Ty's future legs and medical cost.

Ty has been cancer free for almost 3.5 years,though he will continue to have  more scans in the next 2 years to make sure he continues to stay cancer free,  his next set of scans will be September 11, 2012, which will be exactly 4 years to the day that he was diagnosed. We know there are great things in Ty's future and we are praying that Ice Hockey is one of them.

We know were fortunate to have all we have, and it's hard to ask for this help, but our faith in people has grown by leaps and bounds since he was diagnosed.

Thank you in advanced for any help you can give

 

Photo of Ty with some of our local hockey team players..
story_txt:
Our Campaign is for our son Ty, he's a 16 year old cancer survivor. After 10 months of high dose chemo therapy and a surgery, our son became an above knee amputee due to bone cancer in his right tibia. Though he won't always be a cancer patient, he will always be an amputee.
We have been blessed with having decent health insurance due to my husband being active duty and serving in the US Air Force for 21 years. Now retired and not able to find a job and 70% disabled, it's becoming harder for us to afford to pay out of pocket cost for new prosthetic legs as Ty continues to grow.

We have set the goal to what we are expected to pay for just this one leg, anything that exceeds the goal will be set aside for a fund for Ty's future legs and medical cost.
Ty has been cancer free for almost 3.5 years,though he will continue to have  more scans in the next 2 years to make sure he continues to stay cancer free,  his next set of scans will be September 11, 2012, which will be exactly 4 years to the day that he was diagnosed. story:
Our Society was created and registered 2009.  The need was recognized because our life changed in a heart beat in 2006 when we were introduced into the wold of the high level disabled and the very little available to aid recovery.  Every  day I see the day to day overwhelming problems for the persons sitting permantly in a wheel chair, I also see the courage it takes to live the reality of their lives, and their ongoing strength and drive to gain recovery.  Our Society is dedicated to educate the public and to aid the disadvantaged to realize the benefit to physical and mental health that consistent 1 on 1 assisted exercise with specialized therapists and specialized equipment affords.  We were recently introduced to the FES Cycle (functional electrical stimulation) (huge cost $20 Thousand tax incl.).  The person wheels up to the cycle, is hooked up to the cycle and the session is digitally recorded tracking all progress - the benefits are immense - reverse atrophy, improve circulation, range of motion, reduce muscle spasms etc.  This probably doesn't mean much if you don't speak the language of the dis-abled.   For the able bodied it would translate to you putting on your running shoes (by yourself) getting on your bike or running the path through the park - your muscles tone strenghtens, your circulation improves, your heart is healthy, etc (minimum cost). 

What we hope to do is raise the money to purchase a cycle and set up an ongoing program.  If we do not reach our purchase price goal the funds would be directed to the programs we currently have running that assist qualifying disadvantaged that have reached out to us. Our ultimate goal is to grow as a charity and reach a greater number. 

Every small amount of recovery is a goal met, a toe that flicks, an ankle that bends, the ability to bear a small amount of weight on a leg, to be able to reach full height in a standing frame after years sitting in a wheel chair (a child that had never seen her father upright). to be rolled unto your stomach after 30 years - I have been there for these events it is like watching your child take their first steps.  All of the above are second steps and research is showing that consistent assisted therapy is key to reaching these goals.

I tried to get a video uploaded and couldn't.  I tried to think of perks, but I didn't come up with anything except our gratitude for every dollar raised and our wish for your well being in the knowledge of the good that your dollars can do.  We are 100% volunteer and 100% of funds raised goes to aid our assisted therapy programs

HELP US HELP - If you are unable to help with funding we thank you for reading our request.  You can help by sending this message forward - expanding knowledge is recovery it can help the disabled that have given up, or family and friends that are their support.  Recovery can be a change in attitude and attitude can change a life.  Thank You.

story:
Our Story

The Windham Harm Reduction Coalition Inc. was founded in 2009 with the mission of empowering and making a difference in the lives of people involved with drugs, commercial sex workers and their partners/ families through offering comprehensive user driven harm reduction services, education and training.


The Impact

The Windham Harm Reduction Coalition is a volunteer run community health organization. Our agency provides free confidential HIV prevention and other health and wellness services to over 70 individuals in Northeast Connecticut's Windham county. Our Services include:
- Syringe Exchangeâ€¨
- HIV Testing and Counseling Referrals
- Drug Overdose Prevention / Safer Use Trainingsâ€¨ 
- LGBTQ Youth Suicide Prevention Workshops â€¨
- Drug Treatment Referrals
- Housing Referrals


What We Need & What You Get

The Windham Harm Reduction Coalition (WHRC), recently received disheartening news from the North American Syringe Exchange Network (NASEN), who is the largest funder of our agency's work. NASEN announced with regret that they will not be funding syringe exchange programs in 2012. Here is a link NASEN's web-site and their official statement regarding funding for syringe exchange programs in 2012. http://www.nasen.org/news/2011/nov/02/2011-nasen-grants-announcement/

â€¨â€¨Since 2009, WHRC has received $10,000 in annual grant funding from NASEN for the purchase of sterile injection supplies. This funding has been critical in ensuring WHRC's ability to offer comprehensive user driven harm reduction services to residents of Northeast Connecticut. It has enabled WHRC to distribute over 50,000 safe injection kits.â€¨â€¨With the absence of grant funding from NASEN, the Windham Harm Reduction Coalition is in danger of having to scale back and possibly discontinue critical harm reduction services.

We need to raise $10,000 to ensure we remain able to fulfill our mission of providing critical health services  to prevent transmission of Hepatitis and HIV in our community in 2012. At the moment we have enough supplies to continue operating through April 30. Our goal is to raise $2,500 of the $10,000 needed to continue operating this year by April 30. If we are unable to meet this goal will be forced to scale back and possibly discontinue critical harm reduction services.

â€¨â€¨Now more than ever we need your support! Please give generously. A small contribution of $20.00 will allow us to purchase 100 sterile syringes to be distributed through our agency's syringe exchange program.


Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to give at this time but want to help? Please consider organizing a fundraiser to benefit Windham Harm Reduction Coalition. For more information on how to organize a fundraiser please e-mail us at: windhamharmreductioncoalition@gmail.com.

â€¨â€¨

On behalf of the Windham Harm Reduction Coalition, thank you for your contribution towards our life saving work.


â€¨â€¨Chris Heneghan

â€¨Director, Windham Harm Reduction Coalition Inc.

â€¨windhamharmreductioncoalition@gmail.comâ€¨

(860) 234-7313

story:
My name is Robin Engholm and I am personal friends with Liam's family. They lived with me and my family while Liam underwent 4 weeks of daily radiation in the hopes of kicking this disease.He is a fighter and is close to his 1 year anniversary of diagnosis. Things are not going well and if required we will need to move the family closer to Children's Hospital in St Louis MO. He has 2 sisters that are currently over 3 hrs away staying with friends while mom and dad are in the hospital with Liam. We need your help!!! His story, originally written around December is below. He has been through more radiation and chemo than listed as well as an additional Bone Marrow Transplant. This family needs our help! They have been through more than I would ever want to go through as their 6 yr old daughter is in remission from an unrelated type of cancer!!!

On July 23rd, 2011 our world SUDDENLY changed, Liam was diagnosed with Stage 4 Neuroblastoma. We had finally achieved the "American Dream" in Raymondville, Missouri! We had 3 happy and healthy children, summer was in full swing and we finally had all of the love and support of our families within spitting distance from us. Liam had not been feeling well, but like any normal parent we thought it was due to the heat. Then the night of the 22nd Greg went to hug Liam goodnight and he gasp in pain and threw-up. We immediately rushed him to the ER. They said he needed to poop and he had worms. The next morning he was no better and running a fever, so back to the ER we went. A CT scan was ordered. The next thing we know the doctor comes in and gives us the news that he has a massive tumor in his belly region and he is in first stages of Liver failure. The doctor then said that Liam was being rushed to St Louis Children's Hospital in St Louis, Missouri. It took a minute for it to sink in, then WAM! It hit! All I could think about was JUST SAVE MY SON! The tears came flowing and it took everything in me to catch my breath. Once in the hospital all of the tests started. He had to go in for a biopsy and a bone marrow biopsy as well as have a central line put in his chest. Then the wait started for all of the tests to come back. Waiting was one of the hardest things I have ever had to do. I can honestly say the 4 days it took seemed like an eternity. His belly just kept growing! Liam wasn't being treated yet, so it felt like we were watching him die in front of us. Then the results came in. It was confirmed. He has Stage 4 Neuroblastoma and a minimum of 18 months of treatments ahead IF he makes it. We were then told the tumor grew out of his adrenal gland, which is on top of your kidney, pushed out his liver, wrapped around his aorta, then split his diaphragm and settled on the bottom of his lungs. Due to the size of his tumor and where it was it was creating a blister effect causing fluid in his lungs. The next thing we know Liam is being sent down to the PICU and on life support. Those 2 weeks were the longest 2 weeks and full of roller coaster ups and downs. We had to watch our son, crash and turn a horrible color grey, watch them bring him back, and then wait for Liam to decide to fight. He rested and regained strength enough that the PICU doctors wanted to take his breathing tube out again. We were a nervous wreck. We watched and prayed. FINALLY, Liam was breathing on his own. Meanwhile, all of this is going on our other two children, Natasha 11 and Natalie 5, were still in Raymondville with our Grandma. Once we knew, how long of a fight Liam was going to have we had to make a difficult decision to move in with my parents since they are closer than 3 hours to the hospital. So leaving my son in the hospital with Greg, I left to get the girls. I went back to Raymondville loaded what I could in the truck along with the girls and headed back here. The 3 hour trip was full of a lot of questions and tears. All Natasha could say was she was scared. Upon pressing, she was scared her baby brother was going to die and where would she go to school. Fast forward to school starting, the girls were enrolled and ready for their first day. Liam was STILL in the hospital and had not come home yet. They both were a ball of nerves. The bus showed up and they both climbed on. I was nervous for them but knew they were in good hands as both the Intermediate and Elementary schools knew what was happening with Liam. Natasha had told their bus driver, Jennifer Hall, all about Liam that first day. She told the girls she would be praying for him. About 2 weeks later, Liam got to come home for 48 hours. The girls had no idea! They jumped off the bus and went running for their brother. Finally, our family was whole again even for only 48 hours. Liam gets admitted every 22 days for Chemo and has to stay in for 5 days at a time. When he is home, every morning the bus comes and Liam is right there to greet the kids and Jennifer. Liam has finished Round 5 of chemo and pulled thru surgery and his first bone marrow/stem cell transplant. Liam will be going in for bone marrow/stem cell transplant #2 on the 20th of Feb. Keep those prayers coming :)

story:
Hi there!

When I first heard about Buds to Blossoms (.org), I was wrapping up my practicum for my master's in divinity program.  I had been integrating my trainings that showed me the social, ancestral, and personal factors that lead towards the breakdown of families in our culture and the factors that return families to a state of health relatively quickly. Infant massage was a component of my work that was included but I knew more was possible with it.

When I heard that Buds to Blossoms not only brings volunteers to Southeast Asia to massage children with compromised immune systems, but also teaches the children how to massage each other, I got that funny feeling I needed to go.

Up until recently Buds to Blossoms was working with two orphanages in Cambodia where the kids have experienced a tremendous amount of trauma in their young years including abuse, prostitution, and slavery - not to mention the loss of their peaceful country and the loss of their parents.  In just two years, these kids went from violently hitting each other, which was pretty normal for them, to reaching out in care for each other as modeled by the Buds to Blossoms program.       

I find this incredibly exciting because it shows the power that gentle massage has to restore a sense of wholeness, connection, and care for one another despite the amount of trauma and challenges one has faced.  

The children we'll be working with in Vietnam are fairly new to the Buds to Blossoms program.  Apparently they are very thirsty for the massage.  They live in a very understaffed orphanage where it's not unusual for a volunteer to be in a room of 15 kids and 2 or 3 infants.  If the children can learn to take care of each other through massage, my heart will be very happy.

Massage has a tremendous amount of benefits.  It boosts their immune system, it relieves pain....  Studies have shown that adults abused as children decrease repeating the abuse when they take the time to massage their children.  Australia is running a pilot massage program in their elementary school system.  It's proving to be the most favorite part of the children's day and it's significantly reducing incidences of bullying.

I can't help but think that massage is a powerful way to bring more peace into our world. Your contribution or help in spreading the word about this endeavor will make a huge difference in the lives of the orphans and in the work I do with families.  I learn through experience.  Volunteering with the children in Vietnam will anchor in an experience I can draw from for many years to come.

Check out this 3 minute video (the children are from one of the Cambodian orphanages):
 
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.


Here is what the expenses are running to participate for one, two, or three weeks:

Expense:

One Week to work with orphans:

Two Weeks to work with orphans:

Three Weeks to work with orphans:

Buds to Blossoms Program is $750/week

(incl. accomodations, not food)

(pending on when I can buy it)

(hotels, taxes, taxis, etc)

Total Needed per week:

for two weeks

$8,375 - $9,450

for three weeks
So far over $3,745 has been generously donated between this online campaign, a WePay page (see below), and private donations!

If need be, I'll go for one or two weeks instead of three.  Even though I could conceivably save the funds for a year and go next year, it feels like this October is the time to go.  


All contributions to help me answer this "call" to go is greatly appreciated.  

To give a heart donation towards Maritza's personal expenses for volunteer donate on this page. Click the pink "Contribute Now" button near the top of this page.

To make a tax deductible donation towards airfare and program costs, donate at this link: https://www.wepay.com/donations/budstoblossoms-maritzaluzvega

If you want to follow this campaign on Facebook, click here: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Maritzas-Fundraiser-to-Volunteer-at-Orphanages-in-Vietnam/364505580318869


Thank you so much for your support by contributing financially or by helping to spread the word.  The more this page is emailed to you friends, family, and colleagues the more the word will get out to a wider audience.  Please share this link and help make a difference in the world.

Thank you!

Maritza

....If you prefer to send a check or money order, make it out to Maritza Vega and send to P.O. Box 1334 Ojai CA 93024

So far over $3,745 has been generously donated between this online campaign, a WePay page (see below), and private donations!
If need be, I'll go for one or two weeks instead of three.  Even though I could conceivably save the funds for a year and go next year, it feels like this October is the time to go.  

All contributions to help me answer this "call" to go is greatly appreciated.  
To give a heart donation towards Maritza's personal expenses for volunteer donate on this page. Click the pink "Contribute Now" button near the top of this page.
To make a tax deductible donation towards airfare and program costs, donate at this link: https://www.wepay.com/donations/budstoblossoms-maritzaluzvega
If you want to follow this campaign on Facebook, click here: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Maritzas-Fundraiser-to-Volunteer-at-Orphanages-in-Vietnam/364505580318869

Thank you so much for your support by contributing financially or by helping to spread the word.  The more this page is emailed to you friends, family, and colleagues the more the word will get out to a wider audience.  Please share this link and help make a difference in the world.
Thank you!
Maritza
....If you prefer to send a check or money order, make it out to Maritza Vega and send to P.O. Box 1334 Ojai CA 93024

story:
Short Summary On May 5th My daughter called from the emergency room at allegheny general in Pittsburgh ,PA My 14 yr old grandson Merrill was riding his bike and his brakes were not working .He continued down a steep hill and landed head first into a parked car . He was in the trauma unit ,then then a week in the hospital , Fractured wrist subdoral hematoma, DAI are the problems he is battling He is now at Children rehab Inst and is making progress everyday.Learning to walk talk etc Funds needed for my daughters lost wages  also I will help her this summer and take the summer off without pay. My daughter is a single mom w/ a 6 year old at home ,She has a good job and would like to keep it and stay off of public assistance.I am recently unemployed (employer passed away)Timing is right for me to help but finances are not .We appriciate any help we can get. If not please place Merrill in your prayers .Thank You Camille Livengood  

Merrill is a very bright 14 year old and enjoys dragon boat racing and creating his own video games .The image is from the July 4 dragon boat race in Pittsburgh. Merrill is also involved with the ROTC in North Alleghney

story:
Our Story

There is a time when everyone's life where things have gone wrong and you've lost hope. If you haven't felt this way than I pray you never do. If you have than I pray you can sympathize with those who truly need a helping hand.

The backstory to the campaign is pretty simple. My name is Kristen Clark and I'm writing on behalf of my mother Julia Kammerer.There have been situations in my life where we have had nothing but an air mattress and peanut butter with crackers. But the situation has never been as dire or as urgent as the immediate. I'm asking you to help us in this time of need.

My stepfather about two months ago was diagnosed with Stage IV Lung & Liver cancer. He was given roughly about 4-6 months to live. The doctors wanted to do Chemotherapy and Radiation but his liver in such a terrible condition that the aggressive treatment would have killed him. My stepfather decided he would take the route of Hospice and spend his last few months with his family comfortably and in no pain. But what we didn't know was that he wouldn't make those 4-6 months. A few weeks after recievnig the diagnosis he passed away at home. 

My stepfather was very close to being my father and I loved him dearly. My mother loved this man beyond belief and the struggles we're going through makes it even harder to grieve. A day doesn't go by we don't miss the man who made our house a home. 

My stepfather's disability was the reason we were able to live from the month, we barely scraped by but we made it. We were able to live month to month by sheer luck. After his passing my mother learned she will not recieve his disability from the state. The beginning of August the State of Pennsylvania ran out of funding for cash assistance so we recieve no funding from that department. The only thing we recieve from the state if food stamps each month so we can have food on our table. But how do we pay the montly bills?

My mother is disabled from a work related injury. I, Kristen, am the only one with an income that is coming into the house. I work a small part time job at JCPenney and don't earn enough to support us. I can't get another job because they'd cut our foodstamps and take away my medical insurance.

I pay what bills I can while paying my own. I put gas into my car to get to and from work. But we're at the bottom of the barrel and have no financial help from any of my mother's siblings. None of them are really involved in her life.  We're close to potentially getting evicted from our home. We can't afford the bills. We've sought every single avenue for help. We keep looking for doors to open but they keep closing instead. Open a door for us to walk through and feel safe.

We're asking you to help us keep a roof over our head since no one else can. We're asking you to give us a fighting chance. We're asking you to keep a mother and daughter together so we're not forced to seperate if we get evicted. We've already lost our stepfather, we don't want to lose our home.

We're good people with good hearts, we just have been delt a terrible hand. 

We Need Your Help

Any funding we do recieve will go to helping us try to stay afloat while also donating half to local Cancer Institute near us.  Every single penny really does count, because we're simply out of pennies. If you don't have a penny to throw our way, please share our link to your friends. Share it on IndieGoGo. Help us out, please. If we don't recieve all the money in time we'll still split it 50/50. We're good and honest people. 

Please help us in this time of need and be the angel we so desperately need.

We are grateful for every penny, or dollar sent our way. We thank you for ever considering to look at our page or even donating. Thank you so much for your time.

story:
About Us

  • My name is Spencer and I am the founder of Smiling Again. I have long been dedicated to helping those in need, participating in the administration of and donating to various causes. During my volunteer work, I noticed that most donated items fall into a limited range of categories, such as food or clothing. While such items are important, so are infrequently donated and greatly needed items, like oral hygiene products.

Our Aim

  • I believe that a healthy smile is an important aspect of a healthy life. While some people are fortunate enough to own the products needed for a healthy smile, others are not as privileged. This puts them at risk for serious health problems, including gum disease, tooth decay, and heart disease.

  • Smiling Again is committed to solving this problem. We provide shelters in Vancouver with toothbrushes, toothpaste, and other oral hygiene products needed for a confident, healthy, and happy smile.

  • Your support will enable us to help more people than we could otherwise, so donations are welcomed. Every cent helps, and your contribution will go far in bringing a healthy smile to the face of someone in need.

Goals

  • Our goal is to raise at least $1000. This amount enables us to purchase roughly 2000 toothbrushes and over 100 tubes of toothpaste.  If the goal amount is not reached, the funds raised will still be used to purchase toothbrushes and toothpaste.
  • You need not donate a large amount to make a large difference. A donation of $1 allows us to purchase an extra toothbrush, and every cent moves us toward our goal.
  • If you cannot donate, you can still make a difference. Please let others know about our cause, and send them the link to our page.
story_txt:
About Us

My name is Spencer and I am the founder of Smiling Again. I have long been dedicated to helping those in need, participating in the administration of and donating to various causes. During my volunteer work, I noticed that most donated items fall into a limited range of categories, such as food or clothing. While such items are important, so are infrequently donated and greatly needed items, like oral hygiene products.
Our Aim


I believe that a healthy smile is an important aspect of a healthy life. While some people are fortunate enough to own the products needed for a healthy smile, others are not as privileged. This puts them at risk for serious health problems, including gum disease, tooth decay, and heart disease.


Smiling Again is committed to solving this problem. We provide shelters in Vancouver with toothbrushes, toothpaste, and other oral hygiene products needed for a confident, healthy, and happy smile.


Your support will enable us to help more people than we could otherwise, so donations are welcomed. Every cent helps, and your contribution will go far in bringing a healthy smile to the face of someone in need.

Goals

Our goal is to raise at least $1000. This amount enables us to purchase roughly 2000 toothbrushes and over 100 tubes of toothpaste.  If the goal amount is not reached, the funds raised will still be used to purchase toothbrushes and toothpaste.

You need not donate a large amount to make a large difference. A donation of $1 allows us to purchase an extra toothbrush, and every cent moves us toward our goal.


If you cannot donate, you can still make a difference. Please let others know about our cause, and send them the link to our page.

story:
How to Register:

Want to be a Street Bodhi-in-Training?  Email vinyasa@aol.com for a registration form please.  Instructions for payment will follow.

The Story 

108 Monkeys (www.facebook.com/108monkeys) is a nonprofit that started out as a way to bring free yoga to kids' afterschool programs in New Haven, CT. . . Then, their parents, teachers, therapists, counselors, you name it, started asking for it too. We couldn’t say no. We observed something unique happening when both caregivers and their clients have the opportunity to practice mindful movement together. “Street Bodhisattvas-in-Training” is the project we designed around that concept.

 

The Training: What is a Street Bodhisattva?

A Street Bodhisattva is a yoga practioner,  yoga teacher or even nascent yoga enthusiast who wants to bring yoga to an underserved group—e.g., homeless families, disabled individuals, or at-risk kids.  Is that you?

Street Bodhissatvas-in-Training will attend the Street Yoga Training (www.streetyoga.org) over the weekend of September 7-9, 2012, or on September 10-11, 2012, and then spend about 1-4 service hours per week for two months helping a nonprofit partner build a sustainable yoga program in their organization.  

With the guidance of 108 Monkeys, they will collaboratively plan how to appropriately introduce yoga or contemplative practices to the nonprofit’s clients/students.  They will combine what they learned in the Street Yoga Training, the staff’s deep knowledge of their client’s needs, and a strong connection to yoga. With weekly mentoring, the teams will use this to design yoga practices that are ambitious but appropriate, so that the practice of yoga can take root and continue to flourish without additional funding.

On November 10, 2012 we'll have a rockin' graduation celebration to honor all that contributed and participated.

Who Else is Involved?

We are lucky to have great partners.

Street Yoga of Portland, Oregon (www.streetyoga.org) will visit us to give their 3-day training, as long as this fundraiser succeeds so we can pay them! Their fee is $9,000 per training.

Meanwhile, back in New Haven, Connecticut Mental Health Center, Clifford Beers Clinic, and the Boys & Girls Club of New Haven have promised to chip in half of the Street Yoga training costs, free up some time for their staff to be trained, and fund community outreach. Friends at Yale University have offered to put their brains into evaluating the effectiveness of the program.

To top it all off, our generous community yoga studios—Balanced Yoga, Fresh Yoga, The Breathing Room, Your Community Yoga Center, and Bikram Yoga of New Haven—have all committed significant donations of space and/or used mats.

 

The Impact

New Haven, a small city of 124,000, suffered 36 youth murders during the 2011-12 school year.  

 

Violence of this kind is just a symptom.  The disease?  At its deepest level, disconnection from others and from the physiological reality that we are all the same.

Yoga is a tool to re-connect to feelings, and to the truth that our lives are all inextricably intertwined. When we remember how to feel that we are one, empathy returns; with it healthier social patterns. 

After their first yoga class, which the teacher described as "overwhelmingly positive," a New Haven Academy student asked if they could do this again, commenting "We're actually being nice to each other!"

 

What We Need & Why

VOLUNTEERS:

We need volunteers, or "Street Bodhisattvas-In-Training", to commit to doing the program September through November of 2012.  This part of the project is full, thanks to our many great volunteers!  If you would like to be put on a wait list for the 2013 cohort, please email vinyasa@aol.com.

 

$10,008:

108 Monkeys needs to pay Street Yoga to provide the training, and to pay its own staff and project expenses.

The community-building, mentorship components of the program will require fairly intensive labor from our staff. Our nonprofit partners have promised to contribute toward this amount, but we must raise additional funds to cover our administrative costs, like:

  • Insurance and required background checks to cover our volunteers
  • Posters, copying, and gas cards for our hard working interns
  • A set of mats for each nonprofit, to encourage continued practice after the program ends â€¨

From October and November of 2012, our Executive Director will provide formal support during weekly mentoring meetings. There, each team will share what they are doing, and be offered feedback and guidance as necessary. Teams will be encouraged to think deeply about what yoga can offer to the specific site where they are working, be creative in resolving any issues (modifications, noise etc.), and mindfully make use of the feedback expressed by the staff and clients/students at their nonprofit. â€¨

After the volunteers' commitment is over, informal support will continue as the nonprofits move into their first season of independently sustaining what the team built.  This phase will include evaluation of the program and data collection during visits to each nonprofit site.â€¨ â€¨

 

Other Ways to Helpâ€¨

  • Send us your answer the question: “WHO TURNED YOU ON TO YOGA?” â€¨(Video responses will be compiled into a digital quilt and posted, both here and on our other media channels)â€¨
  • Tell us who else in New Haven needs free yogaâ€¨
  • Volunteer your skills in another capacityâ€¨
  • Donate your old matâ€¨
  • And of course, notify all your friends (fb and in person) about this project!â€¨â€¨â€¨â€¨â€¨

 

FAQâ€¨â€¨

 

Why 108?

The individual numbers 1, 0 and 8 represent one thing, nothing and everything (infinity).    108 represents the ultimate reality of the universe as being simultaneously One, emptiness and infinite.

 

108 is the number of

• beads on a rosary

• beads on a mala

• names for Buddha

• letters in the Sanskrit alphabet

• stitches on a baseball

 

Why Monkeys?

That’s us!  Buddha described the human mind as being filled with drunken monkeys; jumping around, carrying on, capricious and fanciful.  Yoga and mindfulness help you get intimate with your whimsical inner monkey.

Our name is also in honor of Hanuman, the monkey God.  Modest despite great strength and wisdom, our monkey Hanuman was a devoted yogi, an expert dancer and a great ambassador.   In one story he jumped the sea to help free Sita; in another he delivered a mountain of medicinal herbs to dying soldiers.  Then put the mountain back in its right place.  Hero, humanitarian and environmentalist; rock on Hanuman! 

 

Can I contribute by check or money order?â€¨â€¨

Sure! Please make it payable to “Elm City Flow d/b/a 108 Monkeys” and mail it to 319 Peck St., Box D-12, New Haven, CT 06513.â€¨ â€¨â€¨

 

Is my contribution tax-deductible?

Yes. We are a federally approved 501 (c)(3) tax-exempt charity. However, note that contributions made through Indiegogo are not tax-deductible. If you prefer your contribution to be tax deductible, you must choose the check option outlined above. Contributors who use the check option will also receive a copy of our tax-exempt status letter, and a receipt recording their total tax-exempt contributions in 2012. â€¨â€¨

When will I receive my perk?

  • Stay tuned to this page for updates, but we expect the series class perks to be hosted by Balanced Yoga of Westville on Saturdays from 7:45 a.m. to 8:45 a.m.â€¨â€¨
  • Volunteers will be contacted by August 1 for registration and further arrangements about the Street Bodhi program.
  • Individual items (cup, hoodie) will be mailed or hand delivered (for those who are participating as volunteers in the program) by Sept 15, 2012.
  • Organizations will be contacted by August 1 to advise on the message.

story:
Hello. My name is Melissa Trujillo. I live in Portland, Oregon. I’m the oldest of three children to Donald and Rose Johnston. My mom has always been my best friend. Growing up she sacrificed everything to take care of my brother, sister, and I. 15 years ago she and my father divorced and my mom has been on a downward spiral ever since never quite getting back on her feet. In roughly 2005 she was advised by her physician that she had the beginning stages of C.O.P.D.- Chronic Obstructed Pulmonary Disease and she was encouraged to quit smoking. Unfortunately she did not(However she has been smoke free for several years now). Her disease progressed so rapidly and she developed Emphysema and was recently advised that she also has fibromyalgia. My mom went from being an active and outgoing woman who loved to fish, camp, spend time in the outdoors, travel, playing with her grandchildren to being housebound. She is on oxygen 24 hours a day/7 days a week. She has 17% use of her lungs and is no longer able to really do much of anything. The highlight of her week is hopefully making a short trip to the grocery store.

Up until February 2012 my mom worked. She was able to maintain employment as an onsite apartment manager which allowed her to basically work from home. As long as she was able to perform her job she had a place to live as well as an income however she did not have health insurance. In February her employment was terminated and she was forced to move from her apartment where she had resided for the past five years. The impact was devastating. That income was the only way she was able to pay for the multiple prescriptions that she is on. They gave her a small severance check. If she were able to maneuver stairs she would have just moved in with me but she is not. All of the restrooms in my home are upstairs and she cannot access them. My mom is essentially alone. My brother is staying with her and helps her with most day to day activities and I am there quite often as I am not working at this time. But she has spent her savings on her medication, monthly utility bills, and personal care items. We have reached a dismal point.

She applied for and was denied unemployment. I helped her apply for Social Security Disability as her first application was denied as well. Her doctors have advised that she is a walking miracle. Most people that are as ill as she is are bed ridden in a hospice or hospital. While my mom can no longer do the things that she has already done and even just using the restroom is difficult there is hope. Her doctors believe that she is a prime candidate for a lung transplant. She will be placed on a waiting list as soon as her insurance begins. She is 56 years young.

I love my mom more than words can express. It is difficult to see her in so much physical and emotional pain. She has to deal with her mortality on a daily basis and is often overcome with fear of what might happen if she does not have access to oxygen. She should not have to worry about prescription drugs or paying her utility bills. I cannot begin to express how grateful we would be for any help. We are asking for $3,000 as I believe this amount is enough to pay for her medication, traveling oxygen tanks, and utilities until we hear from SSI. We’re hoping to hear any day now.

If we do not reach the goal of $3,000 we have asked that my mom is still allowed to keep the funds. Anything will help her. The funds will go to pay for her inhalers, pain medication, portable oxygen tanks, and to help keep her electricity paid. We cannot offer much by way of giving back to you for your generosity but I will send a thank you to every single contributor and I can also keep the contributors updated as to her status. I would like to create a page that would allow contributors to follow her journey and to hopefully see her go on to a full lung transplant and recovery! If you are not able to contribute please spread the word and share our story! My mom deserves more than this. She has six grandchildren that miss her and a family that wants nothing but the best for her. Thank you.
story_txt:
Hello. My name is Melissa Trujillo. I live in Portland, Oregon. I’m the oldest of three children to Donald and Rose Johnston. My mom has always been my best friend. Growing up she sacrificed everything to take care of my brother, sister, and I. 15 years ago she and my father divorced and my mom has been on a downward spiral ever since never quite getting back on her feet. In roughly 2005 she was advised by her physician that she had the beginning stages of C.O.P.D.- Chronic Obstructed Pulmonary Disease and she was encouraged to quit smoking. Unfortunately she did not(However she has been smoke free for several years now). Her disease progressed so rapidly and she developed Emphysema and was recently advised that she also has fibromyalgia. My mom went from being an active and outgoing woman who loved to fish, camp, spend time in the outdoors, travel, playing with her grandchildren to being housebound. She is on oxygen 24 hours a day/7 days a week. She has 17% use of her lungs and is no longer able to really do much of anything. The highlight of her week is hopefully making a short trip to the grocery store.
Up until February 2012 my mom worked. She was able to maintain employment as an onsite apartment manager which allowed her to basically work from home. As long as she was able to perform her job she had a place to live as well as an income however she did not have health insurance. In February her employment was terminated and she was forced to move from her apartment where she had resided for the past five years. The impact was devastating. That income was the only way she was able to pay for the multiple prescriptions that she is on. They gave her a small severance check. If she were able to maneuver stairs she would have just moved in with me but she is not. All of the restrooms in my home are upstairs and she cannot access them. My mom is essentially alone. My brother is staying with her and helps her with most day to day activities and I am there quite often as I am not working at this time. But she has spent her savings on her medication, monthly utility bills, and personal care items. We have reached a dismal point.
She applied for and was denied unemployment. I helped her apply for Social Security Disability as her first application was denied as well. Her doctors have advised that she is a walking miracle. Most people that are as ill as she is are bed ridden in a hospice or hospital. While my mom can no longer do the things that she has already done and even just using the restroom is difficult there is hope. Her doctors believe that she is a prime candidate for a lung transplant. She will be placed on a waiting list as soon as her insurance begins. She is 56 years young.
I love my mom more than words can express. It is difficult to see her in so much physical and emotional pain. She has to deal with her mortality on a daily basis and is often overcome with fear of what might happen if she does not have access to oxygen. She should not have to worry about prescription drugs or paying her utility bills. I cannot begin to express how grateful we would be for any help. We are asking for $3,000 as I believe this amount is enough to pay for her medication, traveling oxygen tanks, and utilities until we hear from SSI. We’re hoping to hear any day now.
If we do not reach the goal of $3,000 we have asked that my mom is still allowed to keep the funds. Anything will help her. The funds will go to pay for her inhalers, pain medication, portable oxygen tanks, and to help keep her electricity paid. We cannot offer much by way of giving back to you for your generosity but I will send a thank you to every single contributor and I can also keep the contributors updated as to her status. I would like to create a page that would allow contributors to follow her journey and to hopefully see her go on to a full lung transplant and recovery! If you are not able to contribute please spread the word and share our story! My mom deserves more than this. She has six grandchildren that miss her and a family that wants nothing but the best for her. Thank you.

story:
INTRODUCTION

Hello - I’m Chris Cain. I have been living with muscle spasms for 25 years due to a spinal cord injury. In my lifetime I have tried treatments from pharmaceuticals to herbal remedies, but the only thing that has worked for me consistently without creating a physical addiction or bad side effects has been cannabis. It is an illegal substance in some states, which makes it difficult to acquire and avoid prosecution by the law. In my hometown, I have been harassed, arrested and accused of being a criminal. I have testified in front of legislative committees multiple times in Austin to bring a medical marijuana bill to a vote, but it has not happened. Because of this, I have researched every avenue of obtaining this medicine without prosecution.  

After learning about CBD oil, I feel I have finally found a way to cure my spasms without fear of legal prosecution, and without having to put tar laden smoke into my lungs for the rest of my life! This is because the oil can be extracted from industrial hemp which contains only minuscule amounts of the psychoactive ingredient, THC. 

While I began my research to find an answer for my muscle spasms, along the way I learned that there are millions of people suffering debilitating neurological disorders that CBD oil relieves. Specifically, some disorders cause children to have dozens of epileptic seizures a day. There are documented cases that show that CBD oil can decrease seizures from 300 per week down to just 1. For all the children going through debilitating seizures and their families who give up their lives to care for them, I have developed the EpiVape - a quick, safe solution that is legal in all 50 states.

INTRODUCING THE EPIVAPE

1. The EpiVape is a cost effective disposable hemp oil vaporizer, shaped differently so vaping medicine will move away from the connotation of smoking as most vaporizers look like cigarettes. 

 2. The EpiVape contains a proprietary vaping liquid consisting of the highest quality CBD oil from World Hemp Oil with a high percentage of CBD. The oil is imported from Europe where it is extracted from the flowering material of industrial hemp using a process to ensure that all of the medicinal compounds in the oil remain intact. 

3. By vaporizing the CBD oil, the medicine enters the blood stream quickly and stops seizures and spasms much faster than ingestion methods. Because there is no fear of a CBD overdose, a child can puff from the EpiVape that is hanging around his/her neck at will to suppress oncoming seizures. 

4. Because people are familiar with the EpiPen, a device used for immediate treatment of allergies, the name EpiVape will automatically be associated with a medical product. In this case, Epi stands for epilepsy rather than epinephrine. It can be used for other ailments as well such as muscle spasms due to spinal cord injury or multiple sclerosis, and tremors associated with Parkinson’s disease among others.

CBD OIL EXPLAINED

Dr. Sanjay Gupta, Chief Medical Correspondent from CNN, publicly supports this natural compound as a real solution to epileptic seizures and muscle spasms. Cannabidiol, or CBD, is a compound in cannabis that bonds with naturally occurring cannabinoid receptors in our bodies located in the endocrine system, the spleen, white blood cells and the nerve cells. CBD, or cannabidiol, stimulates the production of our own cannabinoids. These cannabinoids promote health in ways that are still being discovered. Because it does not contain the psychoactive ingredient, THC, it does not get you high or make you feel stoned. CBD oil is being used to treat symptoms of epilepsy, and muscle spasms caused from MS, Parkinson’s and other neurological disorders.

EPILEPSY STATISTICS

  • One in 100 people will develop Epilepsy.

  • In two-thirds of patients diagnosed with Epilepsy, the cause is unknown.

  • Up to 50,000 Americans die each year from seizures and related causes.

  •  30% of those diagnosed are children. 

  • Uncontrolled seizures may lead to brain damage and death.

  • Epilepsy can develop at any age and can be a result of genetics, stroke, head injury, and many other factors. 

  • For many soldiers suffering traumatic brain injury on the battlefield, Epilepsy will be a long-term consequence. 

  • The current drugs used to treat epilepsy have extreme side effects such as inducing coma and internal bleeding.

http://www.epilepsy.com/node/986825

IS CBD OIL LEGAL IN THE USA? 

You may have heard about Charlotte’s Web, a strain of CBD oil made in Colorado from medical marijuana, which has been in the news a lot lately. Because the oil is extracted from medical marijuana grown in the US, it is not legal to ship or transport it to other states because of the current marijuana laws in this country. Families have had to move their children to Colorado to get help, and this desperate need has resulted in 11 states amending their laws to allow CBD oil extracted from medical marijuana to enter into their states.

However, farmers in Europe are growing organic industrial hemp high in CBD and low in THC, so CBD oil comparable to Charlotte's Web type strains can be extracted from the industrial hemp plant rather than medical marijuana strains. Furthermore, because this industrial hemp oil is imported, it is legal in all 50 states according to the law. The US classifies imported industrial hemp as a dietary supplement. Our partner, World Hemp Oil, has sourced its oil from these quality farmers, and we have developed it into our proprietary vaping liquid for fast results.

http://www.agmrc.org/commodities__products/fiber/industrial-hemp-profile/ 

No longer does anyone have to suffer, waiting for states to pass laws allowing CBD oil that is extracted from medical marijuana.

HOW WILL THE FUNDS BE USED?
We believe this campaign will not only give us the financial resources to move forward with the EpiVape, but through it we will build a supportive community. Together, we can improve the quality of life for people suffering seizures and spasms and their families.

  • 70% for setting up manufacturing 
  • 10% to establish a database of families in need 
  • 20% to setup a distribution and subscription system 

REWARDS

For donators at the $35 level and over, you will be given tickets to a concert event in the Live Music Capital of the World, Austin, Texas in the summer of 2015 featuring top artist(s) to be announced. This concert will be in support of the industrial and medicinal hemp movement. Also you will have the option of one of our t-shirt designs. For $65 you will get a t-shirt and a concert ticket. 

We will be open to new t-shirt ideas throughout the campaign. Please leave your suggestions for different t-shirt slogans! If we pick your slogan idea, you will receive the $65 reward package. If you provide all artwork and we like it, you will receive the $110 reward package!

STRETCH GOALS

If we exceed our initial goal, we will spend the extra funds to expand our marketing and approach major retailers to carry the product. While the EpiVape is branded directly for those with epileptic seizures, we want to expand the branding and packaging for other medicinal needs. We will create proprietary formulas of our CBD oil vaping liquid. We feel that our CBD oil will be the next Omega 3, and vaping medicine will be common once it loses the connotation of smoking a cigarette. Below are two products we plan to introduce if the EpiVape campaign is successful.

VapeCalm - Relaxation, Sleep Aid, Anxiety, Stress
VapeRelief - Muscle Spams, Tension, Cramps

If the crowd funding project is overwhelmingly successful, we will use some of the funds to sponsor a major concert event in support of our EpiVape and the Hemp Oil As a Medicine movement.

The organizers of the concert have agreed to scale the event based on the success of the EpiVape Indiegogo project! Help us to not only change the lives of people in serious need of this medication with the EpiVape delivery system, but to put on the biggest concert possible to raise awareness about the benefits of industrial and medicinal hemp across the world!

If you just can't contribute, here's how you can help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
